channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine News: Kyiv Poised for Major Offensive Against Russian Forces
item.description: With its sights set on Kherson, a vital port city that fell to Putin’s forces in the first days of the war, the Ukrainian military is destroying Russian ammunition depots, hitting command posts and targeting supply lines.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a village retaken by Ukrainian forces from Russian forces near the border of Mykolaiv and Kherson Oblast, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Francis Begs Forgiveness for ‘Evil’ Christians Inflicted on Indigenous People
item.description: The Roman Catholic leader apologized for the church’s role in running boarding schools where Indigenous children were sexually and physically abused and where many died.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis in a headdress at the end of a ceremony on Monday in which he apologized for the Catholic church’s role in abuse at residential schools in Alberta.

item.title: U.S. Officials Grow More Concerned About Potential Action by China on Taiwan
item.description: The Biden administration is watching for any moves by China to close off the Taiwan Strait, and they would prefer that Nancy Pelosi cancel her planned trip.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, David E. Sanger and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Ann Wang/Reuters
item.media:description: Taipei shoppers at dusk. Suspicions in Washington and Taipei of China’s intentions toward Taiwan have increased during the conflict in Ukraine, because Chinese officials have consistently supported Russian rationales for the invasion.

item.title: Where China Is Changing Its Diplomatic Ways (at Least a Little)
item.description: As relations with the U.S. and Europe plummet, Beijing is beginning a new wave of diplomacy in Africa, where it dominates trade with resource-rich nations.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Huang Jingwen/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, speaking by video to a China-Africa forum in November. China’s campaign to cultivate African allegiances is part of a great geopolitical competition.

item.title: Myanmar Executes Four Pro-Democracy Activists, Defying Foreign Leaders
item.description: They were the country’s first executions in more than 30 years. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the ousted civilian leader who was detained during last year’s coup, remains in prison.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Soe Zeya Tun/Reuters
item.media:description: U Phyo Zeya Thaw, left, leaving Parliament with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in Myanmar’s capital, Naypyidaw, in 2016. Mr. Phyo Zeya Thaw was one of four pro-democracy activists executed Saturday.

item.title: Tunisians Vote on Constitution That Could Threaten Their Democracy
item.description: The new charter would enshrine into law a vast expansion of executive power under President Kais Saied in the past year.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Zoubeir Souissi/Reuters
item.media:description: Casting a ballot at a polling station in Tunis on Monday. Most major political parties urged supporters to boycott the referendum on a new constitution.

item.title: Candidates for UK Prime Minister Emulate Another: Margaret Thatcher
item.description: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss have tried to adopt the style and themes of Margaret Thatcher, the Iron Lady whose sweeping right-wing policies remain popular among Conservative voters.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Jacob King/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Conservative leadership candidates Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss during a BBC debate on Monday. Mr. Sunak has said he is championing “common-sense Thatcherism.”

item.title: Russia Cuts Gas Flow to Europe, Intensifying Fears It Is Weaponizing Fuel
item.description: On the eve of a European Union meeting to debate a gas conservation plan to make the bloc less vulnerable to a Russian squeeze, Moscow slashed the flow to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Lennart Preiss/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A natural gas storage facility in Bierwang, Germany, last month.

item.title: As Ukraine Signs Up Soldiers, Questions Arise About How It Chooses
item.description: Recruiters approach young men on the street, but the standards are not always clear and there are reports of unwilling men being signed up while some eager to fight are turned away.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians undergoing combat training in the Ukrainian city of Lviv, in April.

item.title: Last Stand at Azovstal: Inside the Siege That Shaped the Ukraine War
item.description: For 80 days, at a sprawling steelworks, a relentless Russian assault met unyielding Ukrainian resistance. This is how it was for those who fought, and for those trapped beneath the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Pavel Klimov/Reuters
item.media:description: By May, after months of battle, the Azovstal Iron and Steel Works was a charred skeleton.

item.title: Eyeing Kherson, Ukraine Prepares an Ambitious Counterattack
item.description: With soldiers, artillery and subversives, Ukraine has been laying the groundwork to retake Kherson, which Russia has held for months. But a counterattack would require huge resources, and could come at a heavy toll.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times

item.title: ‘We Survived Another Night’: In Ruined Suburb, Solace in a Small Community
item.description: In a largely abandoned apartment complex on the outskirts of Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-biggest city, the people who stayed behind find comfort in their surroundings and each other.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heavily damaged housing blocks in Kharkiv’s Saltivka neighborhood.

item.title: How a Flight Attendant Became a Funeral Planner in the Covid Era
item.description: The pandemic upended careers in Hong Kong and around the world, forcing or inspiring people to make radical changes in their lives.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Louise Delmotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Connie Cheung, 57, taking care of her grandson, Kason Ip, 2, at her home in Hong Kong in July. After her airline shut down, she became a postpartum nanny.

item.title: Congo to Auction Off Oil and Gas Blocks In a Step Back for Climate Change
item.description: Peatlands and rainforests in the Congo Basin protect the planet by storing carbon. Now, in a giant leap backward for the climate, they’re being auctioned off for drilling.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Dionne Searcey
item.category: Virunga National Park (Congo, Democratic Republic of)
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peatlands in Équateur province in Congo last year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine prepares for a counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Kyiv Nightlife Comes Back Amid Urge for Contact. ‘This Is the Cure.’
item.description: Frenzied raves. Crowded bars (with free therapy). And of course, cuddle parties. Nightlife is returning to Ukraine’s capital. But revelers still have to reckon with guilty feelings. Plus curfew.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Laura Boushnak
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Pope Apologizes in Canada for Schools That Abused Indigenous Children
item.description: Francis, responding to longtime pleas from Indigenous people, begged forgiveness for schools where children were forced to assimilate, many were sexually or physically abused and some died.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis visited a graveyard on Monday where children who died at a residential school are buried in Maskwacis, Alberta.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Pope Apologizes to Canada’s Indigenous People
item.description: Also, Myanmar executes four activists and China extends its reach in Africa.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis in a headdress at the end of a ceremony on Monday in which he apologized for the Catholic church’s role in abuse at residential schools in Alberta.

item.title: David Trimble, Peace Prize Winner in Ulster Strife, Dies at 77
item.description: A onetime Protestant firebrand, he surprised adversaries when he helped broker peace in Northern Ireland with the Good Friday pact of 1998.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell

item.title: 2 Killed and 2 Injured in Shootings in British Columbia
item.description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police responded after gunshots were reported in four locations in Langley, southeast of Vancouver. The gunman was fatally shot by the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Shootings on Monday morning in Langley, British Columbia, prompted the authorities to send emergency alerts to cellphones in the area.

item.title: What Is the Pope Apologizing for on His Visit to Canada?
item.description: The investigation took testimony from more than 6,000 witnesses and reviewed thousands of documents over six years.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

item.title: Pope Francis is expected to deliver an apology long demanded by Canada’s Indigenous communities.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Expands Use of ‘Filtration Centers’ for Ukrainians, U.S. Says
item.description: A newly declassified U.S. analysis found that Ukrainians detained in the centers may face deportation or imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: U.K. Will Host Eurovision in 2023
item.description: Organizers had ruled out Ukraine from hosting next year because of safety concerns from Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Ryder of Britain was the runner-up at Eurovision in Turin, Italy, in May.

item.title: The New Abortion Battleground
item.description: The political fight over abortion will increasingly be a battle over the mailing of pills into Republican-run states.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: George Frey/Reuters
item.media:description: Misoprostol, used to terminate early pregnancies.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia looks to Africa.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the grain terminal at the port in Odesa, Ukraine.

item.title: Two Americans Who Were Killed Fighting in Ukraine Are Identified
item.description: Joining the fight “was something that he needed to do,” a close friend said of Luke Lucyszyn.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Siversk, a town in eastern Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seeks Support in Africa
item.description: Also, the W.H.O. declares monkeypox a global emergency and China launches a rocket into space.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Mohamed Hossam/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, at a meeting with his Egyptian counterpart Shoukry, in Cairo, Egypt, on Sunday.

item.title: At Least 17 Migrants Die After Boat Capsizes Off Bahamas
item.description: The tragedy highlights migrants’ growing use of dangerous sea routes to reach the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jasper Williams-Ward and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Royal Bahamas Defense Force, via Reuters
item.media:description: Survivors on an overturned boat early Sunday in a photograph released by the Royal Bahamas Defense Force, which was searching for others believed to be missing.

item.title: Russia Tells Famine-Fearing Africa It’s Not to Blame for Food Shortage
item.description: Badly needed grain has been piling up in Ukrainian ports since Moscow invaded, but Russia’s top diplomat is in Africa saying the West is to blame.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Anton Troianovski and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, addressing the Arab League in Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: On U.S. Foreign Policy, Biden Acts a Lot Like Trump
item.description: The Biden administration has charted the same course as the Trump administration on strategic priorities like China, the Middle East and U.S. military deployments.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden vowed on the campaign trail to break from paths taken by the previous administration.

item.title: Pakistan’s Deadly Flood Season Worsened by Climate Change and Bad Infrastructure
item.description: Monsoon rains have devastated Pakistan’s economic hub, Karachi, adding urgency to pleas to better equip cities to handle more frequent extreme weather.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman, Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Akhtar Soomro/Reuters
item.media:description: Residents wading through flooded streets in Karachi, Pakistan, this month.

item.title: A French University Confronts Medical Crimes and Its Nazi Past
item.description: A report on the University of Strasbourg’s takeover by Nazis during World War II and on medical crimes they committed there sheds light on a period that had been mostly scrubbed from official memory.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the University of Strasbourg’s anatomy building, a small brass plaque is the only public memorial to 86 Jews murdered so that a Nazi scientist could collect their skeletons.

item.title: ‘Abyss of Fear’: Report Accuses Russia of Further Abuses Against Civilians
item.description: Human Rights Watch cataloged a litany of torture, inhumane treatment, arbitrary detention and disappearances in southern Ukraine and said that the atrocities could amount to war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cellar in Bucha, near the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, where a man who was detained for three weeks by Russian troops was found shot through the ear. Abuses committed by Russian forces have drawn global outrage.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Uprising
item.description: What led to the recent protests.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters overtaking the prime minister’s office in Colombo, Sri Lanka.

item.title: Fears rise for a rights activist captured while fighting for Ukraine.
item.description: Russian propaganda has demonized Maksym Butkevych, a former journalist and campaigner who was taken prisoner in the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: ‘Parentese’ Is Truly a Lingua Franca, Global Study Finds
item.description: In an ambitious cross-cultural study, researchers found that adults around the world speak and sing to babies in similar ways.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: Pope Francis Will Travel to Canada to Apologize to Indigenous Community
item.description: Pope Francis will travel to an Indigenous community in Canada to apologize for the church’s role in residential schools that tried to erase Indigenous culture, and where thousands of children died.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line of children’s clothing set along a highway in British Columbia last year represented the children who died at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

item.title: Conductor Dies After Collapsing During Performance in Munich
item.description: Stefan Soltesz was in the middle of Richard Strauss’s “The Silent Woman” when he fell from his podium shortly before the end of the first act.
item.dc:creator: A.J. Goldmann
item.media:credit: Ullstein Bild, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.

item.title: Erdogan Remains a Headache for Biden, Even After Ukraine Deal Help
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey assisted in brokering an agreement to unblock Ukrainian grain but has alarmed U.S. officials on other fronts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sedat Suna/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, center, helped secure a deal with Russia to ease a blockade of Ukraine’s grain.

item.title: Russia Strikes Odesa Port, Stirring Doubts on Deal to Export Grain
item.description: The string of explosions in Ukraine’s most important port came less than 24 hours after the two countries struck a deal on grain shipments, and prompted accusations from Ukrainian leaders that Russia could not be trusted.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A grain terminal at the port of Odesa on Saturday, after a string of explosions hit the city. Before the war, billions of dollars worth of grain was exported every year from the port to countries around the world.

item.title: W.H.O. Declares Monkeypox Spread a Global Health Emergency
item.description: There have been more than 16,000 cases in 75 countries, overwhelmingly among men who have sex with men.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Monkeypox vaccines were still in short supply when the World Health Organization declared the virus’s spread a global health emergency.

item.title: Amid Sri Lanka’s Crisis, Cricket Carries On
item.description: The success of the men’s national team has offered solace to the country, and one fan called the players “brand ambassadors during this time of hardship.”
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Eranga Jayawardena/Associated Press
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters atop a 17th- century fort overlooking the cricket stadium in Galle, Sri Lanka, while the home team played Australia in June.

item.title: Below an Israeli City, a Musical Harmony Belies the Tensions Above Ground
item.description: In an underground reservoir built 1,233 years ago in a city that saw sectarian riots last year, visitors hear a beguiling musical composition that combines Arab love songs with Hebrew poetry.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Pool of the Arches, a subterranean reservoir beneath Ramla, a city in Israel with a mixed population of Arabs and Jews.

item.title: Four Things Nations Can Do to Conserve Energy
item.description: European Union officials have called on countries in the bloc to sharply reduce their natural gas consumption. These are some of the strategies they could use.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Greenwich Park, in southeast London, on Monday. Temperatures in the city surpassed 104 degrees Fahrenheit this week.

item.title: Indoor Games
item.description: When it’s more comfortable inside than out, it’s time to play games.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Russia and Ukraine trade attacks as fighting shifts to the south.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Dmytro Smolienko/Reuters
item.media:description: A resident clearing debris from a house damaged by a military strike in Nikopol, Ukraine, this past week. Russian shelling struck the town again overnight.

item.title: Russian Missiles Strike Odesa a Day After Grain Deal Agreement, Ukraine Says
item.description: The explosions risk destabilizing an international deal meant to reopen shipping routes seen as critical for easing concerns over world food supplies
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Erika Solomon and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The grain terminal at Odesa’s port on Saturday. A Ukrainian official said Russian strikes had caused 10 explosions in Odesa, and that the strikes on the port had caused a fire.

item.title: The Times’s Theater Critic Reviews Stratford’s New Theater
item.description: The Stratford Festival in Ontario opened a glamorous new theater last month that prioritizes the theater itself, not just what surrounds it.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green

item.title: In Japan, Abe Suspect’s Grudge Against Unification Church Is a Familiar One
item.description: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe said his mother’s huge donations to the church bankrupted his family. Many others in Japan have similar stories.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Kyodo/Reuters
item.media:description: Tomihiro Tanaka, president of the Japanese branch of the Unification Church, during a moment of silence for former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a Tokyo news conference last week.

item.title: How the Government Is Failing Americans Uprooted by Natural Disaster
item.description: Climate change is creating a growing class of displaced Americans, and the federal government is struggling to decide how to help them.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Edmund D. Fountain

item.title: The State Department says two Americans died recently in Donbas.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Gleb Garanich/Reuters
item.media:description: Ukrainian military vehicles in the Donbas region this week.

item.title: Spouses of world leaders to join Ukraine’s first lady in a discussion on postwar lives.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Greg Nash/Getty Images
item.media:description: Olena Zelenska, the first Lady of Ukraine, in Washington on Wednesday. Now back in Ukraine, she is holding a teleconference with first spouses from around the world on Saturday.

item.title: Most U.S. States Have Let Their Covid Emergencies Expire
item.description: The wider latitude conferred by a state’s public health emergency was critical to states’ responses to earlier waves of coronavirus cases.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Public school students and staff members from Clayton County, Ga., waited for coronavirus tests in January.

item.title: Russia Agrees to Let Ukraine Ship Grain, Easing World Food Shortage
item.description: Ukraine and Russia signed a deal to lift Russia’s blockade of Ukrainian ports, which has worsened a global food crisis — their most important agreement since the war began.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A barley field in the Mykolaiv region of Ukraine, in June.

item.title: ‘The deal should help us breathe’: Africa welcomes Russia-Ukraine grain deal.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Eduardo Soteras/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Workers unloaded sacks of grain at a market in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, last month.

item.title: U.S. and Ukrainian officials say they’ll wait to see if Russia upholds its side of the grain plan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A worker in a grain elevator in Melitopol, in southern Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Draghi’s Fall Reverberates Beyond Italy
item.description: The downfall of Italy’s prime minister has raised concerns across Europe about the power of populist movements and whether they will erode unity against Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Andreas Solaro/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi at the Senate on Wednesday in Rome.
